sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Prithee kinde Rolfo, let not us be forc'd
To knocke agen. Exit Rolfo.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Captaine Hubba (as I
Conceive brother) goes not along with you;
I met him ſpurring to our houſe, as I came.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: The Princeſſe Scania, by much intreatie
Got leave of the Lord Inguar, his Coronell,
To ſtay onely two dayes; and he is gone
A viſit to his Miſtris. Enter Rolfo.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Welcome Rolfo.
Come, give it me: for we ſhall need no glaſſes. They drinke at the Lines.
Here worthy brother, halfe to your good journey

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Let me ſee brother, Peeps into the pot. you have drunke the full halfe—
Here Rolfo, fill 't agen. Exit Rolfo.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: O ſweet brother, that you co'd ſtay all night,
I ſho'd never be weary of your company. Enter Rolfo.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Nor I of yours brother, and now from the deepe
Bottome of my heart to th' wide mouth of my ſtomacke
I ſpeake it deareſt brother, here's a whole one,
To our next merry meeting —

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Quickely Rolfo, Exit Rolfo.
Fetch it, and be honeſt. O ſweet brother,
That I co'd imbrace you thus for ever, ever. They imbrace.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: I muſt kiſſe at parting. They kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Rolf.
sp.l: Y' are a couple of th' arranteſt kind gentlemen. Ent. Rolf.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Give me the pot: I ne'r drunke i' my life
With more ſorrow, and a better deſire. —

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Here, take Money Rolfo, my brother payd laſt,
I muſt kiſſe thee too Rolfo,
Within, Rolfo. Rogue.

sp.speaker: Rolfo.
sp.l: Anon, anon, ſir. As they kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Nay Rolfo, for all
Your haſte: I muſt (for my brothers ſake) take
Off that kiſſe, from thy now ſweet (though greaſie) lips. They kiſſe

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: And now farewell, but not for ever, my deareſt
And beſt of friends. Rad. we 'll part at t'other Taverne.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Then arme in arme let 's march, moſt worthy brother. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Hubba and Marfiſa.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I could not otherwiſe chuſe, Miſtris (though
Your diſtruſt of my unfayn'd affection,
Kept me thus long from injoying, what I
Moſt deſir'd in a noble way) but come
(Vrg'd by that love, that ever ſhall remaine
With me, whereſoe'r I goe) to tender
The duty of a ſervant, in taking leave
Of you, before my ſuddaine departure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It 's indeed too ſuddaine: and I doe now
Repent the not imbracing, what I was not
Enough good to accept, your love. For, I confeſſe
Though ſomewhat late, I lov'd you more then you
Did me; and ever ſhall unleſſe the fault
Be onely yours, in proving (which I doe
Not yet ſuſpect) a changling. I ſhall for
My part, puniſh ſeverely in my ſelfe,
Th' offence of not being yours, by a continu'd
Sadneſſe and griefe, till once agen I ſee you.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: And though I have beene too much noted for
My mirth (which yet, was never ſawe'd with ſpite,
Or other bad condition:) I promiſe
(Por my misfortune in thus miſſing of you)
Not to laugh once (unleſſe againſt my will,
At ſome unlucky chance) till I poſſeſſe
The treaſure I moſt covet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That (if you
Meane me) ſhall be yours when we meete next, and
Safely kept for you, untill then. I' th' meane time,
I ſhall charily preſerve (though but a poore
Satisfaction for you) your image in
Th' interior of my minde.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Which overpay's,
With much advantage, all my ſervices.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 't was a ſtrange reſolution of the King,
To leave his Queene, ſhe being ſo much againſt it;
And he ſo ſtrangely fond of her at firſt:
Which ſhe deſerv'd, being a Lady the world
Cannot match.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: He is theſe thirtie houres in Denmarke:
Where if he prove unkinde to her, that cannot
(In true judgement) condemne others, that like not
Such proceeding.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He had neede be circumſpect
In what he do's; or he may ſoone repent it,
And perchance,
When matters prove paſt remedy to him,
Yet, while I find you ſound: no alien faults
Shall make me hate, what once I ſo affected,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Reſting on that aſſurance, I muſt now
Crave the kind, favour of a parting kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That you ſhall have they kiſſe and halfe a dozen more,
When you come to your Ship: For, ſo farre I
Will with you; and wo'd along to Denmarke, but to try
If I may build upon your conſtancie. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Harold and Eric.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: It's now but need, we both looke to our ſelves:
Or we may pay the forfeyt of our ſlackeneſſe
(With the loſſe of both our heads) upon a Scaffold.
For, Reyner having caſt the faire Landgartha
Off, (of whom he was not worthy:) and by
A dreadfull precipice, fall'n from much goodneſſe:
He will not ſtop at his firſt fault. But (hurri'd
By the guiltineſſe of his Conſcience)
Runne headlong downe the hill, upon the rocke
Of dangerous miſchiefe; to which he 's now ingag'd.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: She is a Lady of ſo ſtout a heart,
That when ſhe finds him baſe (although ſhe lov'd him
Exceedingly) ſhee cannot but be reveng'd
For her repudiation, and diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And may prove our ſtrong friend to ruine him;
That has threatned (and that not privatly)
To rid himſelfe on us.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: And will, if he can:
You may by his death then, that wo'd be yours,
Settle your ſelfe ſecurely in his kingdomes,
By matching and partaking now with her.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Brother, the man whoſe deitie we adore
(And who to give us reſt, ſtill liv'd without it)
Can witneſſe for me, could I but perſwade
My minde by any probabilitie,
't were poſſible, for me to live in peace here,
And not have my throat cut: although my right
Unto the Crowne of Denmarke be apparant,
My title while I ſlept or wak'd, ſho'd ſleepe;
As when King Reyner liv'd a vertuous kind man.
For I delight not in th' expence of bloud;
Though I feare not to ſpend my owne in a
Iuſt cauſe. But ſeeing all reſt is deni'd me:
As the ſtrong law of nature binds, I muſt
Shift for my ſelfe, the beſt I may. Which ſhall not
Be effected by baſe trechery, or murder.
Nor doe I chiefly yet meane to rely
On th' brave Landgartha's aſſiſtance; whom the
Love of a wife, and hope of reconcilement,
May urge beyond all ſpirit of revenge.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: What is 't you meane to plot then for our ſafetie?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: We'll to the pious Chriſtian Emperor,
Lewis the Debonaire; who (as you know)
Do's oft ſolicite me to plead my right
To th' Crowne, by dent of ſword; that being the beſt
(Nay onely) Patent, Reyner has to ſhow for 't.
Though he from 's father got it: which doth leſſen
Much his guilt.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: It's not his guilt that now moſt troubles him;
But by more ſinne to guard it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Twelve thouſand.
Expert Souldiers (that lye neere here, o' th' borders
Of Germany) I may have when I liſt;
To adde (with all ſpeed) to our owne ſure friends.
And unto others that will fall in troopes,
From now diſhonour'd Reyner, for his baſe
Adultery intended with Vraca,
To ſtrengthen himſelfe againſt his wife and me.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: Vnheard of madneſſe, ſo vilely to betray
(And to 's owne ruine) a poore and vertuous Lady;
That but for him, and his damn'd ſhameleſſe lyes,
Had never marry'd any. Being withall
(As 't is reported) moſt extreamely faire,
Farre, farre beyond the other,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Such are the follies
Of humane nature, when it is forſaken
Of him that made it: But we'll now make uſe on't.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: You ſho'd be ſuddaine, leaſt we be layd hold on;
And to take him unprepar'd.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: When night aſcends
Her ſable charyot, we will both of us
(Mounted on our beſt horſes) poſt away;
And be (I hope) cre we be miſs'd, paſs'd danger.
Come, let us therefore in, and looſe no time:
Which, in neceſſitie 's a fatall crime. Exeunt.

div.head: The fift Act.
div.stage: Enter Valdomar and Jnguar.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: You are happy beyond expectation
In your Embaſſage: for all men did conceive
(And very probably) the Queene would ayde
With th' utmoſt of her pow'r, Harrold in his
Deſigne for Denmarke. But, ſhe noble Lady,
(Although in outward ſhow, ſhe have not granted
What you demand) I know (ſuch is her vertue
And loving nature) is comming in her minde,
Now to aſſiſt your moſt ungracious King.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: For which in chiefe he is to you beholding;
Though he deſerv'd it not, at his departure.
But now, Contrition has wipt off his guilt,
Though not the puniſhment, before the gods.
Nor is there any hope left us on earth,
But what we now may gaine here by your meanes

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Had you but beene a witneſſe of her griefes
(Able to rive a heart of ſteele) you had
Melted (as we almoſt did) into teares:
Eſpecially when ſhe heard of th' infamous
Marryage, with Swealands daughter (told her by
A whiſpering flatterer:) how then ſhe tore
Her golden hayre, and us'd ſuch cruelty
On her faire limmes, which had wellneere ended her
(Notwithſtanding what we could doe to hinder 't:)
Curſing the time when ſhe e'r ſaw a Dane;
Not for her husbands renogading moſt:
But the loſſe of her virginitie, and foule
Diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: We heard of all: Yet, were compell'd
By ſtrong neceſſitie (perforce) to build
On her heroicke goodneſſe, and your worth.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: 't was well conceiv'd; and better put to tryall,
That compulſion may worke peace agen.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Here the divine Lady comes (her ſelfe) unto us. Enter Landgartha, Scania, Elſinora, Fatyma, & Marfiſa in womans apparell with Swords on.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Although (Lord Inguar,) your ſoveraigne, and my
Unkind husband, were rather to expect
Sharpe warre and hate then any ayde from me
In his diſtreſſe: having (as farre as 't lay
In him) diſgrac'd me by his flight; and as
I 'd us'd falſe play with others: yet, my love
To him (deepely engraven in my heart.)
Ioyn'd to my owne innocence and merit, has
(As all may ſee) got the upper-hand; and ſtopt
My once intended courſe of ſtrict revenge;
Though he enjoy another wife, now the Miſtris
Of what is mine by bond.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Moſt gracious Queene,
I can ſay nothing, to excuſe his guilt;
Or leſſen it: but that your vertue ſhines
The brighter for his deepe ingratitude,
Which now 's the greateſt Corroſive to himſelfe,
And cauſe of all his evils, by the loſſe
Of in a manner all was his before:
And that his act, has render'd both of you
Famous to all the world, in different manners:
You as the glorious mirrour of all worth,
But him (with griefe I ſpeake it) for 's offence.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: Which now (deare Madame) as it is repented,
Exacts your mercy more then puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Elſin.
sp.l: To prove a laſting Pyramid to all
Succeeding times, of ſuch a noble act.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: It can yeeld you no benefit to ruine
Him and his poore ſubjects, being alſo yours;
And in their loves, they're yours.

sp.speaker: Fat.
sp.l: Much more then his
I doe beleeve.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Madame. I can depoſe it. To Fatyma.
And that they 've ever deem'd it their chiefe glory,
To have had her for their Queene; their hearts he loſt,
When he loſt her: nor is there ought can rayſe
The minds o' th' few, that now ſticke to him, but her
Strong aſſiſtance, and the try'd vallor of the
Norwegian Ladies, that before
Gave us the victory againſt the Swedes.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: King Reyner and your ſelfe (Lord Inguar) have
Too many friends here, to be deni'd in what
Our pow'r may ſtead him, or you demand.
And I'm the more induc'd to pardon his fault,
That I acknowledge my ſelfe faultie too
(And which my heart has oft accus'd me for,
With no ſmall griefe) in granting that to him
Vnder the flattering title of marryage, which I
Reſolv'd ne'r to 'a' loſt; and which he durſt not
Seeke to have forc'd from me. But it 's now paſt helpe.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: There 's one way yet left (Madame) to helpe all.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: He then tranſported, by his fierce deſire,
Which ſlav'd him: by craft (I'll give it no worſe
A name) did that wrong to my modeſtie,
Which I (being not ſo deepe in paſſion)
Might well have hinder'd; and by yeelding to it,
Have given ſcope for others to condemne me.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Which none can juſtly doe: For, I'm aſſur'd,
Madame (though you have cauſe not to beleeve it)
That his intents to your grace, were ſincere
At firſt, as now they are: and therefore (deare Queene,)
You are to meete his paſt ill, with your goodneſſe.
Which, if you doe not ſpeedily: there will be
No time, nor meanes hereafter, left for you
To exerciſe your vallor in this cauſe.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: When we behold our neighbors houſe on fire,
The Proverbe ſayes we ought looke to our owne:
This you conceive; and I ſuppoſe you are
Inform'd by theſe that love you, that we have
As many valiant men and women, in
A readineſſe, as may, if heaven be pleas'd
(For we are pleas'd in 't) reinthrone your King;
And chaſe thoſe rebels that now urge his flight.
Let then my brother (the Prince Valdemar)
And you, make all the haſte you can before us;
With newes of our approach. And, one thing more
I muſt intreat you doe for me: which is
To deliver this Letter, unto him that
Caus'd my ſorrow; and left me great with child.
Which fruit of his, he ſhall ſoone looke on, young Frideſlaus.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: He ſho'd 'a' ſtayd, to have got
Such another.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: In honeſty, he could
Have done no leſſe.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Your graces Letter, I hope
Within theſe three houres, he ſhall reade at furtheſt.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: You 'll give me leave to goe before, to provide
A lodging for you?

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: Yes: for I meane to be
Your bedfellow to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: And I ſhall ſtrayne my ſelfe, to bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: The King will doe as much too, for your Highneſſe.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Fy, not ſo ſoone man, that were a ſhame indeed,
People wo'd then ſay, that I went to aske it. ſmilingly
Nor does he neede me; having one (at leaſt)
Already to keepe him warme.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: He thinkes of none,
But your Grace.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: We muſt be now abrupt in our
Leave taking?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Be gone Scania, fare you well. Inguar, may all
The gods be your guides. Exeunt ambo.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: And now Marfiſa.
Silence declares with you, how gladly your heart
Conſents, to goe for Denmarke.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I meane to doe
Your Majeſtie ſome ſervice there, now that
You meaſure my affection by your owne.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: But what, if you come to weare the Willow garland,
By the inconſtancie of Captaine Hubba?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not (doe as the Queene did) forgive the offence.

sp.speaker: Fat.
sp.l: No leſſe then 's life would ſatisfie your anger.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Doe you make doubt on't?

sp.speaker: Elſin.
sp.l: I beleeve him honeſt.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: What is your owne opinion? Marfiſa.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I ſtill ſuppoſe the beſt.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Then wayte upon
My couſin Fatyma: and both of you make haſte
To ſummon with all ſpeede (on paine of death)
All our troops (both men and women) in Anſtoy,
Saltſburge, and thereabouts. Our Siſter and Aunt
Shall to the neerer quarters; whilſt I prepare
Here all things requiſite for our departure.
And as we once made no ſmall haſte to meete
King Reyner, when he brought us ayde againſt
Our foes: let's doe the ſame in gratitude
(And with more honour) now, in aſſiſting of him.
Thoſe which we leave, will keepe ſafe here. Away.

sp.speaker: Fat.
sp.l: The truſt impos'd on us, we 'll not betray. Exeunt omnes ſeverally.

div.stage: A march. Then enter Harrold, Eric, and Lothaire arm'd.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: We muſt make haſte, Lord Lothaire, (now that by
The helpe of heaven, for which we chiefly move:
And the aſſiſtance which you Lord and ours,
The noble Emperor Lewis, true inheritor
Of his great fathers vertues did afford us,
We are aſcended to what is our right,
Being thereto lifted by your manly worth too)
To make all ſure, by joyning our laſt iſſue
With Reyner, ere the brave Landgartha come
(Whom he once more thinkes to deceive:) For, where
Shee leads, all goes to wracke i' th' other ſide.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: It 's ſtrange ſo ſtout a minde as hers, ſho'd ever
Yeeld love or obedience to a man that has
So baſely dealt to her.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: She ſquares all her
Actions by the rule of goodneſſe, not
Of paſſion; and thinkes this deede of hers,
A very gratefull offering to her gods,
Yet, we doe hope to ſend (before ſhe land here:
Her husbands rancke ſoule, to great Belzebub.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Then let's march on with ſpeede; and truſt our cauſe
To him, that only gives life by his lawes. Exeunt a march.

div.stage: After the march, Enter Reyner and Hubba.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Heare you no newes from Inguar (Hubba) yet

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Not a word: But a ſhip is now on entring
In at the haven; and we hope it 's his.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: No, no. We are of all the world forſaken,
But moſt of heaven: For, we have deſerv'd it,
And our repentance now comes too too late.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I doe beſeech you ſir, not to yeeld to
Such weake, unmanly diffidence.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: We wrong'd
Thee (Hubba) too; and now thy loyaltie
And kindneſſe wounds our ſoule deeper, then if thou hadſt
Prov'd falſe, all turnes to my confuſion.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: It was your paſſion and not you, ſtrucke me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Would I were quickly dead, or never borne,
To ſee the evils which I have occaſion'd,
And muſt needs feele, if I but live a while.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Your noble Queene Landgartha, will I doubt not
(If i' th' meane time ſir, you doe what lyes in you,
With patience) ſoone rid you of thoſe feares;
And State you as before; and in her love too.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: I ne'r ſhall ſee that Halcyon day againe,
To ſee her, Hubba, though you all ſuppoſe
The contrary; and caus'd me ſend to move
Her goodneſſe. She is too magnanimous
Ever to looke at ſuch a wretch as I am,
That deceiv'd her once ſo foulely.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You'll finde
Your ſelfe deceiv'd, I hope ſir, in that ere long.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Had I but faithfull prov'd to her, as ſhe
Deſerv'd (thou know'ſ it Hubba,) I might then
'a' playd at ſtoole-ball with young children, or
Have waſted time more idlely, if I'd liſted;
And have my eſtate multiply'd to many
Kingdomes. Now, thou ſeeſt, we are not worth one
Province, Stricke me heaven. Enter Valdemar and Inguar.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Honeſt Captaine, I
Am glad to meete you alive.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Your Highneſſe poore ſervant.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: The King walkes ſtrangely ſad.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: He's not himſelfe: and therefore, whatſoever
Newes you bring; y' had neede uſe your accuſtomed
Diſcretion in the relating of it.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: You are both as welcome hither, as my
Diſtraction will give me leave to bid you.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I never knew you (ſir) too much exalted
At flatt'ring Fortunes ſmiles, or when you Conquer'd:
And (now ſhe frownes) you ſtill ought to preſerve
A valiant indifferencie.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Healthy men
Know how t' afford good counſell unto others,
Whoſe forces being too weake, to beare the blowes
Of their diſeaſes, yeeld and languiſh under
The waight that 's inſupportable.

sp.speaker: Jng.
sp.l: The weaker
Their minds are, the more they yeeld; beyond
Neceſſitie: and thereby become chiefe Actors
In their owne Tragedies.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: I know you ſpeake this,
To prepare my minde, for the bad newes you bring.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Your vertue will now moſt conſiſt, in not
Being over joy'd, when you read this Letter,
Written and ſent by her, that ſayes ſhe loves you.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Let me ſee 't. I know the hand, it's hers,
O let me, let me kiſſe it, kiſſe it ſtill, Kiſſes the Letter.
And not preſume to looke what it contaynes,
To plague my guiltie conſcience. Vald. reade and be rul'd.

body.p: If this my ſecond duty, may prove as happy in the recovery of thy kingdomes, as my firſt was against a Tyrant; yet honouring thee with the victory; J ſhall account my travell well beſtow'd. Make head bravely (as wiſedome permits) againſt the enemie: for I am comming with all ſpeed, to let him know, that Landgartha (being thy Queenne and only lawfull Wife) is a warrior: and will prove ſo to his prejudice, and thy advantage: having from her heart (notwithſtanding thy unkindneſſe) abſolv'd thee of all the wrongs thou did'ſt her.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: A gracious language! O you gods defend me,
From turning altogether foole at this. For, my
Frayle veſſell is not able to contayne,
The forcible exceſſe of this ſweet comfort.
My ſoule reſults ſo ſtrangely, mounts, mounts up,
That I have much adoe, to keepe from dancing:
My nimble ſpirit elevats my body,
And my very life (I thinke) will now with joy
Forſake me, fly away.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Be not in extreames,
So like a meere franticke Pray recall your wits,
Before ſhe comes, you may looſe all; your ſelfe, and us.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Excuſe me, worthy Couſin, you feele not
The force of my impulſion. Yet, I confeſſe
I'm (but as others are) a poore weake man;
Subject to many changes 'gainſt my will.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Collect your ſelfe, were 't but in obedience Enter ſcout.
To your wiſe and noble Queene. What newes with you?

sp.speaker: Scout.
sp.l: That Harrold and his brother Eric, with
A mighty pow'r of Danes and Germans, march
Hither with ſpeed, doubtleſſe to force a battle.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Which we muſt decline, till our beſt ſouldier
Come: and then we are for 'em.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Lead us from hence,
To guard your works; and doe not now forget
(Your wiſh'd ayde being ſo neere you) your old vallor;
And judgement to command.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I hope we ſhall not. Exeunt.

div.stage: A march. Enter Harrold, Eric, Lothaire, and one or two more with Battle-axes.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Our foes have fortifi'd themſelves ſo ſtrongly,
With Waggons, Carts, huge tymber, and deepe trenches:
As 'tis impoſſible almoſt to force 'em.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: Which if you doe not, you'll finde it a worſe taske,
To quayle Landgartha; whoſe fleet's now at ſea;
Nay hard on landing.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Th' preſent attempt will not
Perchance, prove ſo dangerous, as to th' eye
It ſeemes; if we valiantly ingage
Our ſelves in th' onſet.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Let us boldly on then;
And to conclude what hitherto, we have
So proſperouſly atchiev'd. I will beginne:
And die, rather then looſe what I have wonne. Exeunt.

div.stage: Allarums, A while after which is begun, enter Reyner and Valdemar with Battle-axes.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: All 's loſt beyond recoverie, they are broke
Vpon us in, and fight like hungry Lyons,
Tearing our men to peeces, that now leave,
In foule diſorder.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Doe you (whil'ſt I charge up,
To give ſome ſtop unto their furie) rally
And hearten yours, the beſt you may. For, if
We can hold out, but one full houre: the noble
Landgartha (that with ſpeed incredible,
Has almoſt landed all her forces) will be
With us, to mend all agen.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: She ſhall never meet me flying. Exeunt. allarums.

div.stage: Enter Landgartha, Scania, Elſinora, Fatyma, and Marfiſa: The foure Ladies, like Amazons. Marfiſa with her Gowne tuck'd to th' midleg, ſpurs, &c. As in the firſt of the third Act; Battle-axes withall.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: You heare this Muſicke, Ladies, and perceive
What need our friends have of our ſwift aſſiſtance.
We are not therefore now, to inſiſt upon Here the Allarums ſound as farre off.
A tedious conſultation; or on words
By me deliver'd, to encourage thoſe
Whoſe worths I know already. Doe you Aunt
(Aſſiſted by Fatyma and Marfiſa)
Lead halfe our Armie: and wheele round about
(With ſpeed and ſilence) to charge ſtrongly home,
Upon our enemies backes. My ſiſter and I
Will to our Husbands, that are hardly preſt;
Their men all routed, and a number ſlaine.
Farewell, I hope that we ſhall meete againe. Exeunt ſverally allarums.

div.stage: Allarums. Then enter Reyner at one doore, and Harold at the other.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Stand Traytor!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thou uſurper, I will ſtand;
And could afford you other glorious titles:
But that I meane not (having met you) to
Waſte time in words, untill your fooliſh ſweet-heart
(Whom you wo'd ſtill deceive) come to your reſcue.
But now, I hope you never ſhall enjoy her,
You know how.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: You ſhall know ſomewhat from me, howſoever.

stage.hi: Here they fight, and Harrold beats Reyner under him; on which Landgartha enters, beats in Harrold and returns.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Is it you? I were not beholding, to Land. Exit.
Have done this for you now. Goe, look to your ſelfe & people.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Deare heaven, where am I? or, is this a dream? Reyner riſes as ſhe beats in Harrold.
It was Landgartha ſure. O no, it was not,
That glory and great miracle of the world,
Could not afford ſuch grace to me, the meere
Fall'n dregs of villanie. But yet, 't was ſhe,
The figure of her heavenly face, was once
(And ſtill is) ſo imprinted in my ſoule,
As 't is impoſſible I ſho'd forget her,
Therefore you gods, heape all thoſe mountaynes on me,
Which the impious Gyants lifted againſt you,
Or ſincke me downe into the very Center,
That I may ne'r behold her any more,
That is ſo like you, both in ſhape and goodneſſe.
For, both I have contemn'd, and my moſt baſe
Ingratitude, never appear'd at full;
Till now. O Iove, pownd pownd me with thy thunder,
For, my confuſion is the worſt of torments. Enter Scania and Valdemar.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: The King 's in danger; and we had need make haſte
To diſingage him.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: That 's done (I hope) already.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Welcome deare Siſter, I am aſham'd to looke
You in the face.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: We heard (ſir) you were in danger.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: I was: But now may (when I liſt) goe take
A nap. Wo'd the infernall dogs would teare
My limbs to callops: or adde ſome worſe torment
Unto my minds affliction.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: You neede not
Afflict your ſelfe ſo much, for ought we ſee:
For, now the wheele is turn'd to your advantage;
My Siſter is friends with you too, ſir.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: She ſay'd
My life, when I was downe; and ready to
Receive the laſt (and mortall) blow. But then,
Gave me ſo ſad a looke, O loving Siſter,
That life which is her gift, if I muſt keepe
In her diſpleaſure, is much worſe then death.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: Sir, if you will be rul'd by me, you muſt not
Expreſſe too much, thoſe vehement affections:
For, ſhe's acquainted but too well already,
With your ſad paſſion, and the continuance of it.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Seeing you (deare Lady,) in love and wiſedome,
Eſteeme that my beſt courſe: I ſhall be dumbe
As night, calme as the calm'ſt evening after
A ſtormy day. Scania, let's follow, where ſhe went then. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Harrold and Eric.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: After our loſſe and watching theſe two nights,
I cannot brother (the toyle of our journey,
Lying ſo heavy too, on my tyr'd body)
But ſleepe a little, though it be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: My neede's no leſſe; a little ſleepe will ſerve.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Let's take it here then, the place being ſolitary.

div.stage: They ſleepe, and a ſweet ſolemne Muſicke of Recorders is heard, then enter an Angel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Heaven has decreed, another day
Shall gaine what you have loſt. Your way
Take both (as you were forc'd before)
Unto the pious Emperor.
One of you ſhall be King: whoſe ſeed
Shall be ſo too, untill 't all bleed.
Then (when that iſſue is extinct)
Norway and Denmarkes whole precinct
Shall be rul'd by Landgartha's line,
And Reyners. Her the pow'rs divine
Will (for her Morall vertues) turne
A Chriſtian, ere ſhe come to th' Urne:
Yeeld faith to this: For, without doubt,
What I have ſayd ſhall come about. Exit Ang. then Eric ſtirs and wakes Har.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: Sir, you ſleepe exceeding ſoundly: Pray wake.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I now am freſh enough; Come let's be gone.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: Dream't you nothing, while you ſlept?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: No, did you?

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: Me thought I heard a moſt heavenly Muſicke;
And that an Angel did appeare: and wiſh'd us,
Betake our ſelves againe to th' Emperor,
That what we loſt, another day ſho'd purchaſe;
And that the faire Landgartha (as the reward
Of her Morall vertues) would be made Chriſtian,
Before ſhe di'd.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Though we afford no credit
Vnto ſuch dreames: Yet, we muſt ſteere our courſe
That way; there being (after ſo great a loſſe)
No comfort left, where our foes are ſo ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: Heaven will in time (I hope) revenge our wrong. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Cowſell and Radgee.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Come brother Radgee, it is now concluded,
We ſhall never part agen.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: O deare brother,
I never had a good day on't (much leſſe
A good night) ſince (being barr'd the comfort of your
Sweet converſation) you parted from me.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Nay brother, I can howle the ſame ſad Madrigall
Too: For looke you brother, we were all ſo frighted
By thoſe fat-foggy Germans (who men ſay
Are nothing but fleſh and belly:) that we durſt
Allow no time for mirth and drinking.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Very
Strange that brother. For, they ſay themſelves are
Exceeding good fellowes.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Iuſt of that ſeize.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: I'll tell you more what I heard ſpoken of 'em,
Brother, they 're ſowre: and never worth the truſting,
Or honeſt i' their bargaines, untill they
Be drunke, or at leaſt halfe drunke.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: That's as true,
Brother, as that you and I drunke halfe a ſcore
Flaggons yeſternight a peece. The North winde
Is not ſo bitter in a morning, till he
Has tooke a buttrum, or his Wine.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: And then,
Makes as good Muſicke, as a Bag-pipe when it's
Full blow'n. What doe you thinke of the Swedes? brother▪

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: They are not (yet) altogether ſo good drinkers,
As th' Germans are: but well fall'n to 't of late.
Which makes me ſuppoſe, brother, they'll be beaten
Out too. For beſides, the King will no more kiſſe
The Queene Vraca, as't is ſpoken: But ſticke
To 's owne old Camrade, being indeed the fairer.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Yet, in my opinion brother: his Grace
Being marry'd to both, ſho'd doe exceeding well,
To keepe both ſtill: Sleepe betwixt both 'a' nights.
And imbrace both by turnes. What ſay you brother?

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: What? But to concurre with you? and for many
Good, and convincing reaſons. 's for example:
The King being kept ſo warme on both ſides, by
Two ſuch delicate cre'tures, 't were impoſſible
He ſho'd catch cold; I, or perchance be troubl'd
With Coughs, Scyaticas, or other bone-ach;
And to have Swealand and Norway at command,
Were a matter of no ſmall importance,
You conceive me, brother.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Few wiſe men better,
In part. But, ſtand aſide: themſelves are comming. Floriſh.

div.stage: Enter Reyner, Landgartha, Valdemar, Vraca, Scania, Inguar, Elſinora Fatyma, Hubba and Marfiſa; the Norwegian Ladies in womans apparell, with Swords on; Marfiſa with her Gown untuck'd and ſword on.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: You will not (gracious Madame) thus deceive
The expectations of your poore, and loving
People: whoſe whole hopes, comfort, ſafetie (nay all
We can for the preſent, or hereafter call ours)
Are but benefits deriv'd from the fountaine
Of your warme bountie; at whoſe goodneſſe yet,
We moſt rejoyce. Doe not then (deare Empreſſe,) ſtrike
Sorrow to our lately bleeding hearts; that ſtill
Pant (and not ſlowly) by our former feares;
And the ſore ſtripes we tooke: Which, but for you,
For ever were incurable; and now
By your forſaking of us, will feſter worſe
Then before.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: That you neede not feare, Lord Inguar.
For, I ſhall ne'r be wanting in my care,
And love unto this Nation. Leaving here
The beſt halfe of our Army, now behinde us;
To prevent all future miſchiefes.

sp.speaker: Jng.
sp.l: Our diſhonour
In your departure, we ſhall ne'r recover.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: My offence (which now 's my worſt affliction,
With what it does occaſion) all may ſee,
Tooke origen and iſſue, more of humane
Frayltie, and fooliſh pride: then want of love
To you; or of deſert in you, to merit
A better and more pow'rfull man then I am;
Th' worlds onely Monarch, if there were but one,
For which, I (without your mercie to reſtore me
Once more unto your heart, as to my kingdomes)
Muſt ſpend my dayes (which ſhall not then be many)
Like to a ſickely beaſt without a ſoule.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: My heart ſhall ſtill receive you: But, on my word,
Th' reſt of my body you ſhall not enjoy, ſir,
I now am gaunt you ſee,
All though you muſt not have a feeling of it;
And if I doe play falſe, my belly will ſhow't
Queſtionleſſe: For, I am fruitfull if
I ſho'd be touch'd.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Although but weakly, Madame.
On you, and this your kinde friend: but that I wav'd
Him for my husband, that deſpis'd me as
His honeſt Mate; and wo'd 'a' lov'd me for
By-blowes. Therefore, enjoy him ſtill: for, I ſuppoſe
You are a Hen, that muſt be trod.

sp.speaker: Vrac.
sp.l: That 's more then you know; or I hope ſhall finde.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: She ſhall ne'r enjoy me; nor has not
Of a long time I'll ſweare, if that will ſerve.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: It ſhall not ſir) beleeve it. Yet, ne'r feare
You ſhall be arm'd i' th' front by me; which is
A wrong this other Lady cannot doe you,
If ſhe wo'd.

sp.speaker: Vrac.
sp.l: I'll leave that now for you, that have
The abler bodie.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: And you the frayler minde.
But if you chop words with me thus, or inſult:
I may (for a farwell) cracke your birds necke,
Before we part.

sp.speaker: Vrac.
sp.l: I muſt not ſtand ſo neere
You then. She ſteps behinde Reyner, and holds him betwixt Langartha and her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Nor I prove any ſafeguard for you. Steps from betwixt them.
But ſho'd take part with her, whom I love beſt;
And has beſt right unto me.

sp.speaker: Ʋrac.
sp.l: That you ſay
To flatter her, and for meere feare. But if
I had you in private, I know what you
Wo'd ſing; and play too, if I ſho'd but yeeld. Land. runs at her, and Elſinora ſteps in.

sp.speaker: Elſin.
sp.l: What doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: That I will ne'r have him,
That is reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Elſin.
sp.l: Your reſolution
(I muſt ſay) in that, is worſe then madneſſe.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I'll not quarrell with you, Aunt. Yet, doe admire
A Lady of your know'n modeſtie, ſhould be
So farre miſtaken, and in ſuch a cauſe.

sp.speaker: Elſin.
sp.l: It's you that are miſtaken: I confeſſe.
I was at firſt an oppoſit in your love
Vnto the King: but, ſeeing you would needs
Yeeld (then) your virgin Forte unto his Higneſſe:
I now wo'd have you take what wives doe uſe;
And let me ſtill live chaſte, that doe profeſſe it.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: My Aunt ſayes more (to me I am ſure ſhe did:)
All ought to live according their vocation.
And not prepoſterouſly prove aliens to it.
Nor will it ſerve to ſay he tore the bond,
Now that he's ſorry for't: For, ſtill the generall good
Muſt be preferr'd to all particular
Merit; or that devotion that may
By fooliſh zeale, prove a too great offence.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I muſt heare more opinions, ere I part
From my ſtrong purpoſe: therefore ſir, adieu.
Be mercifull in chiefe, unto your ſubjects;
To allure their hearts, by love: that being the tye
That will hold ſtrongeſt; never can be broken,
Vnleſſe by fooles, or mad men. For, that partie
That ſho'd tend any miſchiefe, 'gainſt a good Prince:
Were firſt to kill all his ſubjects, being the Kings friends;
Or periſh himſelfe, by his fatall and bad
Purpoſe. Be juſt and vertuous, and you neede not
Feare poyſon, poynards, or conſpiracie.
To end: Norway ſhall be preſerv'd for your young ſonne;
And as for me (though yours:) I'll end my life,
An honeſt widdow, or forſaken wife: Exit with Elſinora, Fatyma, & Marfiſa

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I muſt take leave too.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Farewell, worthieſt Couſin.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: You know the way to Norway, Sir, and if
I might adviſe ſo wiſe a King to follow
Us thither, and not ſlowly: that honourable
Obligation would ſo bind your Queene
(Being ſeconded by us your friends, and reaſon)
That I beleeve what now ſhe does denie,
She wo'd then grant; eſpecially, when ſhe
Perceives you conſtant in your vow'd affection:
For this perchance ſhe do's to tempt and try you.
Nay, I am ſure ſhe do's; and that ſhe will be
Yours againe, if you perſever in your love to her,
In the meane time, I ſhall not fayle to prove,
Your grace's faithfull, loving advocate.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: In you the anchor of my truſt lyes only fix'd,
Deare ſiſter. I muſt follow your adviſe. kiſſes her.

div.stage: Exit Scania & Valdemar.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: O brother, brother: muſt we part at laſt? They imbrace. Exeunt Cow. & Radgee.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: No, no: get afore; I'll ſteale along with you.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Inguar, Did'ſt thinke our hopes ſho'd end in this?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: It may prove better; and I hope it will ſit.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Accurſed Fate of man, of fooliſh man,
That cannot prize a Iewell while he has it,
Till it be loſt, and then his griefe is vaine,
Vaine and unprofitable, when no hope
Is left to finde it, which I feare's my caſe;
Our miſerie the mirror's made, by which
We onely ſee our faults, our dangerous wounds.
Which likely then can never be recur'd:
Being Gangreene filthy ſores, that doe Corrode
So farre into the very ſoule of man,
That they hale to ſad deſperation.
To which point I'm almoſt arriv'd, the Gemme
I loſt, being ſo rich, as all earths Potentates
A richer could not boaſt. Which if I finde not
(Strucke with my dyre misfortune) my owne hand
Shall ſend my ſpirit to the Stygian ſtrand. Exit with Ing. & Hub.

sp.speaker: Vrac.
sp.l: And ſeeing I've walk'd aſtray, I will from hence:
By future good to expiate my offence. Exit in the middle.

div.head: EPILOGVE.
Scania (that ſpoke the Prologue) now delivers the Epilogue, apparelled as in the laſt Scene, with her Sword and Belt in her hand.
div.l: THough our Author cares not, how his Play may take:
Yet, cauſe he purpoſes not to forſake
In his affection, any Worthy here;
He hath ſent me 'fore the Court breake up, to appeare
For him agen; to ſee how it hath pleas'd:
For, notwithſtanding he meanes to be eas'd;
For ever of th' like taske: Yet, from his heart
He wiſhes, you and he ſho'd fairely part.
And this he more (for him) deſir'd me ſay:
Where others ſpend a yeare about a Play
(Picking a ſentence here, a word from thence)
This Tragie-Comedy with the expence
Of leſſe then two Moneths time he pen'd: For he
's not too ambitious of the dignitie
Of a prime Poet; which he needs muſt know,
The Muſes chiefe (Apollo) doth beſtow
But very rarely. Himſelfe he knowes too
Better i' th' Art, then ſome that to be ſo
Thought worthy, maligne him. If this pleaſe you,
It's all he 'll aske of Hellicon: Adieu.

div.p: Some (but not of beſt judgements) were offended at the Concluſion of this Play, in regard Landgartha tooke not then, what ſhe was perſwaded to by ſo many, the Kings kind night-imbraces. To which kind of people (that know not what they ſay) I anſwer (omitting all other reaſons:) that a Tragie-Comedy ſho'd neither end Comically or Tragically, but betwixt both: which Decorum I did my best to obſerve, not to goe againſt Art, to pleaſe the over-amorous. To the reſt of bablers, I deſpiſe any anſwer.
This Play was firſt Acted on S. Patricks day, 1639. with the allowance of the Maſter of Revels.
